caption: The management of this fan zone during the opening ceremony was immeasurably stupid. The zone was only 50% full with more than 3x the number of people watching from in between the large surrounding prison walls and the foliage outside. Even worse, as people left the zone, they did not let anyone else in, so the zone slowly became almost empty whilst lots of people were outside the zone and could have enjoyed unobstructed views inside. Additionally, the screen placement was horrendous and it did not need any obstructing graphics around it. Awful atmosphere and showing of the Olympics. One young girl even tried to sneak in to the emptying zone and was removed by 4 guards/police. Crazy. Zero management or care for the people‚Äôs enjoyment. Police would‚Äôve been far better placed protecting people to the sides of the crowds, as many people were almost hit by cars and motorbikes.

A town hall serving the people. A very beautiful building that shines in the heart of Paris. In the 11th arrondissement of course.

overall worst town hall I have been to.... Sick wife, dad often abroad, and the town hall's refusal of a place in daycare... Low salary.... The reasons are nebulous, but we have to manage to find a place 3 weeks before the deadline... because yes, they are having a committee on December 12th for January 1st. There is obviously no help or alternative offered. I requested an appeal at the point where I was on the street, I didn't even get an email acknowledging receipt. no one to signify, warn, exchange. If I had not moved almost by chance, I would not have been informed. It's terrible to leave so many people in the jungle and to fail in our model of mutual aid. And to top it all off, it's a "socialist" town hall... Some socialists would be ashamed. In short, I will spread the message.

Reception, politeness and cleanliness to be completely revised, especially in the securities department where an idiot this day between noon and 2 plays the little chief corporal, refusing a person before me on the pretext that she was 5 minutes late for her appointment while not respecting not the order of arrival of the public. So distressing stupidity that I left without waiting any longer after wasting 30 minutes! Pitiful service!

For the wedding of my best friends, the mayor preferred to do a quiz on the town hall of the 11th arrondissement and the eco labels responsible for the establishment than to speak to them.  A wedding is not the time to put on your green-washed ad. No respect.  What a shame...

Today July 11, 2024 at 12:20 p.m. service PS 11 social office of the town hall of the 11th on the phone an unpleasant aggressive woman who releases me to send me to another service in another neighborhood with no kindness, zero advice. She didn't want to give her name!  How does a woman of this mentality work in social work in a town hall???  Well done the town hall of the 11th super human service!!!  INTOLERABLE !!!!!

We were in a complex situation.  Ms. Raynaldy, the head of the Civil Status service, was extremely efficient, she knows the French laws related to her service, and therefore was able to process and understand our request faster than anyone else ( notaries, embassies, other town halls, etc.).  Finally, someone from the public service who knows the details and is therefore capable of resolving an unusual, even unique, situation.  Her assistants, Ms. Vuibout and Ms. Laisney, are very pleasant, and efficient, too.  Bravo to these three people who are raising the bill for public services!

Good morning,  I think it will be a good idea to place these ‚Äúyellow M poles‚Äù which mean the metro station for the entrances/exits of the P√®re Lachaise metro stations also in my ‚Äúopinion‚Äù also like in these photos that I publishes as an example because I work in the neighborhood and with the P√®re Lachaise cemetery there are often quite a few tourists (and others) in the neighborhood who are passing through etc. and as an employee every time I take breaks they I happen too often to be asked "where is the metro station here" when it is right in front, I think that since there is little visibility especially at night this ‚ÄúYellow M pole could well help/serve and provide a lot of visibility especially when it starts to get dark because on my way home during the day or at night I come across metro stations with this yellow M pole like at the Yellow M station. metro ‚ÄúGambetta‚Äù or ‚ÄúSaint Maur‚Äù for example I realize that it makes a lot of difference in terms of visibility when you are on the sidewalk opposite or a little distance from the stairs of the metro station.

On the right side of the Mary, you can find a Paris water fountain to fill empty bottles for free. The water is very good. An explanatory table describes the composition of Paris water. 1 avenue Parmentier Paris 11th. Accessible 24 hours a day.

A very lively neighborhood. Used to be the home of artisans and craftsmen, but those days are mostly gone with gentrification and the old workshops have been transformed into upscale apartments. The neighborhood is also full of young people, especially in the evening when the cafes are packed. Great place for long walks. The 11th arrondissement is not "touristy", like some central districts. But, there is a very particular atmosphere here, which is due to the population of the neighborhoods. This district is not the most populated (155,000 inhabitants), but the densest in population. Mostly young, dynamic and trendy, in certain neighborhoods, such as along Boulevard Voltaire, with the streets from North to South: Oberkampf, de la Roquette, and de Charonne. Likewise, the district is framed by three prestigious squares, to the North "La R√©publique", to the South East "La Nation" and to the South West "La Bastille". Around the Bastille, many bars, restaurants and nightclubs offer nighttime activities. During the day, the area is lively with many restaurants, notably Rues du Faubourg Saint Antoine and de La Roquette;  To the north, rue du Faubourg Saint Martin, offers popular bars, restaurants and concert halls. For those who want to have a good evening, the 11th arrondissement offers plenty of choice. In these neighborhoods, nightclubs or cabarets, "trendy" bars, offer themed evenings, including: Gibus 18 rue du Faubourg du Temple (dico, funk, house music), Cith√©a Nova at 112 rue Oberkampf , is an underground concert hall, popular with young people. Rue de Lapp, where there are clubs and bars galore, the Chapelle des Lombards is an institution in the "Tropical" style as well as the famous "Bal √† Jo". The Palais des Glaces at No. 37 rue du Faubourg Saint Marin is a One Man show venue, where all the well-known artists perform. The Bataclan, located at 50 boulevard Voltaire, is an establishment in the style of a Chinese Pagoda. After the massacre of November 13, 2015, it got a makeover with a brewery and resumed its concert activities. Finally, the Cirque d'Hiver, at No. 110 rue Amelot, near the "Filles du Calvaire" metro station, offers the Bouglione circus and also variety shows.  the 11th arrondissement also has lively areas during the day, around the three squares, but also in the neighborhoods, with shops of all categories, restaurants, and squares and gardens for taking a break. The squares are spread throughout the district, including that of La Roquette, at number 143 of the street, with pleasant and diverse spaces. That of Emile Gall√©, is a little gem of romanticism, south of rue de Charonne, at 39 rue Neuve des Boulets, Finally, all along the boulevard Jules ferry in the north to the Bastille in the south with Boulevard Richard Lenoir, the city of Paris, has organized very diverse green spaces on the central plain. There are shades, plantations, relaxation areas and water jets. Street markets are also held on all major thoroughfares, particularly on Sunday mornings on Boulevard Richard Lenoir. The district town hall is located at Place L√©on Blum (Place Voltaire).

I went to the town hall of the 11th arrondissement for a PACS application submission in February of this year. The only words that come to mind are rudeness and incompetence. I had an appointment at 12:15 p.m. The first agent, in addition to being unpleasant, left me in the hands of one of her colleagues, a so-called ‚ÄúPACS expert‚Äù because I was encroaching on her lunch break. To make it short, my partner was born in France but of Portuguese nationality. French law stipulates that, to enter into a civil partnership, only a French birth certificate is necessary for a person in this situation. French civil status takes precedence over Portuguese nationality. But obviously, the town hall of the 11th, in addition to not mastering the laws in force, believes itself to be above them! My file was refused because apparently I "did not read the notice correctly" (note which does not mention any information on this "particular situation"). It was then explained to me that it was imperative to request from the Portuguese consulate a certificate of non-pacs and a customary certificate for my partner, otherwise it would be impossible to enter into a civil partnership. I took the liberty of pointing out to them that this is not what the government and the public service indicate (supporting evidence). I was therefore condescendingly told that "it is not because you are born in France that you are French. And that in these cases, you have to ask for nationality and that you should have asked for it." long before." We therefore paid for the supposedly necessary and obligatory documents. In the meantime, we moved and continued our PACS journey at the town hall in the 12th arrondissement. Who gave a completely different speech and welcomed us with extreme kindness in addition to being really competent. Our new interlocutor, after checking our file, focused on the consulate documents and explained to us that they were ABSOLUTELY NOT NECESSARY. In conclusion, the 11th arrondissement town hall wasted our time and money. In short, deplorable service and to be avoided.
Place Voltaire.  Green spaces not well maintained and plants not great. Benches always occupied by homeless people throwing their trash... Too bad

I had an appointment to collect my very first passport. While a town hall employee was taking care of me, one of his colleagues, who was behind him, started to insult me ‚Äã‚Äãand said racist remarks to me. I quote ''she doesn't have a passport, but she's going back to her country'', ''I'm sure she wasn't born here'', ''She's not a real French , she must not speak the language''. The gentleman who took care of me told me not to take her into account. I am outraged; I was born in Hauts-de-France, like my ancestors. French is my mother tongue. Above all, what shocks me is how one can say such things? By a town hall employee? Who exactly do you think you are? I will never set foot in this town hall again if it means being insulted like this. Please review your hiring or firing methods.

Well renovated, welcoming. Information on one-off activities is sometimes missing but the staff very kindly replaces the missing posters. We see that the town hall does everything it can for its citizens. It's nice.
